text: the u.s government has won its appeal at
the high court in london over the
extradition of the wikileaks founder
julian assange
two senior judges ruled that he should
be extradited to stand trial in the u.s
to face espionage charges for publishing
classified military documents relating
to the u.s wars in afghanistan and iraq
well this isn't the final word we should
say mr assange can still appeal
in further processes here speaking after
the judgment julian assange's fiance
stella morris said the decision was a
blow for press freedom in the uk
julian represents the fundamentals of
what it means to live in a free society
of what it means to have press freedom
the uk imprisons journalists
they're imprisoning julian
on behalf of a foreign power which is
taking an abusive
vindictive prosecution against a
journalist and this is what it's about
let's cross our legal correspondent
dominick casiani who is at the court of
appeal
dominic what is the next legal stage in
this
well giza if you see from the ribbons
behind me these yellow ribbons tied all
around the royal courts of justice it's
pretty clear what julian assange's
supporters think of him they think he's
a warrior for truth and justice who's is
at the heart of an appalling conspiracy
involving the uk and the us to put him
on trial for telling the truth about u.s
war crimes but today the law chief
justice in the high court said that
whatever his supporters think of him
there is a case for him to answer in the
u.s and critically the u.s has now given
very key assurances that mr assange no
matter how mentally ill he may be
will be treated humanely and it's these
assurances that washington gave in the
last few months which are at the heart
of this reversal of the case which means
he's very very close now to extradition
in essence guitar what they said is
washington said that they wouldn't put
him in the harshest forms of solitary
confinement they wouldn't put him in a
so-called super max prison which is
reserved to the worst terrorist
defenders in the united states and also
on top of that they said even if he were
convicted of 18 offenses of computer
hacking and leaking the state secrets he
could apply to serve any sentence he
received in australia where he's from
rather than in the us that was enough to
convince the two of the most senior
judges in the country that washington
had met these concerns that julian
assange could be treated properly now
where does he go from here it's very
difficult to say to be perfectly frank
his team are saying we're going to try
to go to the course
to the supreme court they did that once
before years ago and the supreme court
ruled against them they could try again
but it's a very very very long shot so
to be frank time may actually now be
running out for him dominic cashioni
thanks very much indeed
well i'm joined now by reporters without
borders is rebecca vincent who's been
attending mr assange's court hearings
and monitored this one remotely uh mr
assange is going to have to face justice
eventually in the u.s isn't he
well i would frame it completely
differently because i don't think this
is a question of justice we were
extremely concerned about the substance
of the january decision which did not
find in favor of press freedom or
journalism the ruling against
extradition was of course only on mental
health grounds which is why we've now
ended up in this situation today but for
us this case is absolutely about
journalism julian assange has been
targeted for his contributions to
journalism for publishing information in
the public interest and the case that he
might face in the u.s is based purely on
the fact that the us espionage act does
not have a public interest offense
allowing them to bring this case against
a publisher for the first time so the
implications that this could have for
journalism around the world
are really alarming this this will set a
dangerous precedent for many years to
come if there is not success in another
step of an appeal here
obviously prosecutors say that this
isn't about journalism this is about

utterly uh wrong
and you know ultimately if he believes
in his case why doesn't he just go and
argue his case in the us
he is facing possibly 175 years in

conditions of solitary confinement
whether or not it's special
administrative measures uh this is
somebody who's not well who is well
documented to have severe mental health
issues he is unlikely to survive these
conditions so let's put it that clearly
this is a matter of possible life or
death for julian assange well that is
not what that is not what has has been
decided today in fact they've said that
the mental health issues uh you know are
not uh serious enough to to uh back
assange's case here and at the end of

well this is a frankly a polling
decision by the uk high court which is
gambling with julian assange's life but
i don't want to focus just on the
humanitarian concerns here because this
is for us and for many other free
expression organizations around the
world a politically motivated case he
has been targeted for publishing
information in the public interest that
should not be a crime uh the u.s law
needs to be amended and
we quite frankly uh will continue to
campaign for uh his release uh in the

publishers and sources okay
